* Osteoporosis
* Flexibility exercise
* The structure of a joint

title: Aging changes in the breast: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes in the Breast**

With age, a woman's breasts lose fat, tissue, and mammary glands. Many of these changes are due to the decrease in the body's production of estrogen that occurs at menopause. Without estrogen, the gland tissue shrinks, making the breasts smaller and less full. The connective tissue that supports the breasts becomes less elastic, so the breasts sag.

**Changes in the Nipple**

Changes also occur in the nipple. The area surrounding the nipple (the areola) becomes smaller and may nearly disappear. The nipple may also turn in slightly.

**Breast Lumps**

Breast lumps are common around the time of menopause. These are usually noncancerous cysts. However, if you notice a lump, make an appointment with your health care provider, because breast cancer risk increases with age. Women should be aware of the benefits and limitations of breast self-exams. These exams do not always pick up early stages of breast cancer. Women should talk to their providers about regular physical examinations and mammograms or other imaging to screen for breast cancer.

**References**

Davidson NE. Breast cancer and benign breast disorders. In: Goldman L, Cooney KA, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 27th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 183.

Lobo RA, Suh Y. Menopause and aging. In: Strauss JF III, Barbieri R, Dokras A, Williams CJ, Williams Z, eds. Yen & Jaffe's Reproductive Endocrinology. 9th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 14.

Walston JD. Common clinical sequelae of aging. In: Goldman L, Cooney KA, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 27th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 24.

7/15/2024

**Aging Changes in the Breast**

\n\n**Causes of Aging Changes**

As women age, their breasts undergo several changes due to hormonal fluctuations and the natural aging process. These changes can be caused by a variety of factors, including:

*   **Hormonal changes**: Decreases in estrogen levels during menopause can lead to changes in breast tissue.
*   **Aging of breast cells**: As women age, their breast cells naturally deteriorate, leading to changes in breast texture and appearance.

**Types of Aging Changes**

There are several types of aging changes that can occur in the breast, including:

*   **Fibrocystic disease**: A condition characterized by lumpy or rope-like breast tissue.
*   **Cysts**: Fluid-filled sacs that can form in the breast.
*   **Benign tumors**: Non-cancerous growths that can occur in the breast.

**Symptoms of Aging Changes**

Women experiencing aging changes in their breasts may notice a variety of symptoms, including:

*   **Breast tenderness**: Pain or discomfort in the breast tissue.
*   **Lumps or bumps**: Abnormalities in the breast tissue that can be felt during self-examination.
*   **Changes in breast texture**: Deterioration of breast cells leading to changes in breast texture and appearance.

**Diagnosis and Treatment**

If you are experiencing symptoms of aging changes, it is essential to consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment. Your doctor may recommend:

*   **Mammogram**: A low-dose X-ray that can help detect abnormalities in the breast tissue.
*   **Biopsy**: A procedure that involves removing a sample of breast tissue for further examination.
*   **Surgery**: In some cases, surgery may be necessary to remove benign tumors or cysts.

**Prevention and Self-Care**

While aging changes are a natural part of life, there are steps you can take to maintain healthy breasts:

*   **Regular self-examination**: Performing regular self-examinations can help detect abnormalities in the breast tissue.
*   **Mammogram screenings**: Regular mammogram screenings can help detect breast cancer and other abnormalities early on.
*   **Healthy lifestyle habits**: Maintaining a healthy weight, exercising regularly, and eating a balanced diet can help reduce the risk of breast cancer.

title: Aging changes in the face: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes in the Face**

The appearance of the face and neck typically changes with age. Loss of muscle tone and thinning skin gives the face a flabby or drooping appearance. In some people, sagging jowls may create the look of a double chin.

Your skin also dries out and the underlying layer of fat shrinks so that your face no longer has a plump, smooth surface. To some extent, wrinkles cannot be avoided. However, sun exposure and cigarette smoking are likely to make them develop more quickly. The number and size of blotches and dark spots on the face increase as well. These pigment changes are largely due to sun exposure.

Missing teeth and receding gums change the appearance of the mouth, so your lips may look shrunken. Loss of bone mass in the jaw reduces the size of the lower face and makes your forehead, nose, and mouth more pronounced. Your nose may also lengthen slightly.

The ears may lengthen in some people (probably caused by cartilage growth). Men may develop hair in their ears that becomes longer, coarser, and more noticeable as they age. Ear wax becomes drier because there are fewer wax glands in the ears and they produce less oil. The hardened ear wax can block the ear canal and affect your ability to hear.

Eyebrows and eyelashes turn gray. As in other parts of the face, the skin around the eyes gets wrinkles, creating crow's feet at the side of the eyes.

Fat from the eyelids settles into the eye sockets. This can make your eyes look sunken. The lower eyelids can slacken and bags can develop under your eyes. Weakening of the muscle that supports the upper eyelid can make the eyelids droop. This may limit vision.

**References**

* Brodie SE, Francis JH. Aging and disorders of the eye. In: Fillit HM, Rockwood K, Young J, eds. Brocklehurst's Textbook of Geriatric Medicine and Gerontology. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:chap 95.
* Perkins SW, Floyd EM. Management of aging skin. In: Flint PW, Francis HW, Haughey BH, et al, eds. Cummings Otolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery. 7th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2021:chap 23.
* Walston JD. Common clinical sequelae of aging. In: Goldman L, Cooney KA, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 27th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 24.
* Wong CH, Mendelson B. Facial aging and anatomy of the facial nerve. In: Farhadieh RD, Bulstrode NW, Mehrara BJ, Cugno S, eds. Plastic Surgery: Principles and Practice. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2022:chap 62.

**Review Date**

7/15/2024

**Updated by**

Frank D. Brodkey, MD, FCCM, Associate Professor, Section of Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Madison, WI. Also reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

**Learn how to cite this page**

(Note: The "Learn how to cite this page" section has been removed as it is not relevant to the cleaned output.)

**Aging Changes in the Face**

As we age, our faces undergo significant changes that can be both noticeable and concerning. In this article, we will explore the various ways in which our faces change as we grow older.

*   **Loss of Muscle Tone**: One of the most noticeable effects of aging on the face is the loss of muscle tone. As we age, our facial muscles become weaker, causing our skin to sag and lose its firmness.
*   **Thinning Skin**: Another effect of aging on the face is the thinning of the skin. As we age, our skin becomes thinner and more fragile, making it more prone to wrinkles and fine lines.
*   **Wrinkles and Fine Lines**: Wrinkles and fine lines are a natural part of the aging process. However, they can be exacerbated by factors such as sun exposure and cigarette smoking.
*   **Bags Under the Eyes**: As we age, our eyelids become weaker, causing bags to form under our eyes. This can make us look tired and older than we actually are.
*   **Drooping Eyelids**: Weakening of the muscle that supports the upper eyelid can cause it to droop, which may limit vision.
*   **Grayish-White Ring on Cornea**: The outer surface of the eye (cornea) may develop a grayish-white ring as we age.
*   **Loss of Pigmentation in Iris**: The colored portion of the eye (iris) loses pigment as we age, giving many older people the appearance of having gray or light blue eyes.

**Changes in Face with Age**

The changes that occur in our faces as we age can be both subtle and dramatic. Some of the most noticeable changes include:

*   **Loss of Facial Fat**: As we age, our facial fat begins to break down, causing our face to appear thinner and more gaunt.
*   **Sagging Jowls**: The loss of muscle tone in our faces causes our jowls to sag, giving us a double chin-like appearance.
*   **Lengthening of the Nose**: As we age, our nose begins to lengthen slightly due to the loss of bone mass in the jaw.
*   **Ear Changes**: Our ears may lengthen as we age due to cartilage growth. Men may also develop hair in their ears that becomes longer, coarser, and more noticeable with age.

**References**

For further reading on the topic of aging changes in the face, please see the following references:

*   Brodie SE, Francis JH. Aging and disorders of the eye. In: Fillit HM, Rockwood K, Young J, eds. Brocklehurst's Textbook of Geriatric Medicine and Gerontology. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:chap 95.
*   Perkins SW, Floyd EM. Management of aging skin. In: Flint PW, Francis HW, Haughey BH, et al, eds. Cummings Otolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery. 7th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2021:chap 23.
*   Walston JD. Common clinical sequelae of aging. In: Goldman L, Cooney KA, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 27th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 24.
*   Wong CH, Mendelson B. Facial aging and anatomy of the facial nerve. In: Farhadieh RD, Bulstrode NW, Mehrara BJ, Cugno S, eds. Plastic Surgery: Principles and Practice. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2022:chap 62.

**Review Date**

This article was last reviewed on July 15, 2024.

title: Aging changes in the female reproductive system: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes in the Female Reproductive System**

As women age, their reproductive systems undergo significant changes due to declining hormone levels. One clear sign of aging is when menstrual periods stop permanently, marking menopause.

**Perimenopause**

The time leading up to menopause is called perimenopause, which can begin several years before the last menstrual period. Signs of perimenopause include:

*   More frequent periods at first, followed by occasional missed periods
*   Periods that are longer or shorter
*   Changes in the amount of menstrual flow

As hormone levels decrease, physical changes occur in the reproductive tract.

**Menopause**

Menopause is a normal part of a woman's aging process, typically occurring around age 50. With menopause:

*   The ovaries stop producing estrogen and progesterone.
*   Egg release ceases, making pregnancy impossible after menopause.
*   Menstrual periods cease; confirmation of menopause requires no periods for 1 year.

Other changes include:

*   Thinning, drying, and irritation of vaginal walls
*   Increased risk of vaginal yeast infections
*   Decreased external genital tissue, potentially leading to irritation

Common changes associated with menopause include:

*   Hot flashes, mood swings, headaches, and sleep disturbances
*   Problems with short-term memory
*   Decrease in breast tissue
*   Lowered sex drive and sexual response
*   Increased risk of osteoporosis
*   Urinary system changes, such as frequency and urgency
*   Loss of tone in pubic muscles, potentially leading to prolapse

**Managing Changes**

Hormone therapy with estrogen or progesterone may help alleviate menopause symptoms like hot flashes or vaginal dryness. However, hormone therapy is not suitable for every woman due to risks. Discuss the benefits and risks with your provider.

To manage problems like painful intercourse, consider using lubricants during sex, vaginal moisturizers, or applying topical estrogen to thicken vaginal tissues and increase moisture and sensitivity. Your provider can help determine the best course of action for you.

**Additional Tips**

Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and staying engaged in social activities can help the aging process unfold more smoothly.

---

**Aging Changes in the Female Reproductive System**

As women age, their reproductive systems undergo significant changes due to declining hormone levels. One clear sign of aging is when menstrual periods stop permanently, known as menopause.

**Perimenopause**

The time before menopause is called perimenopause, which may begin several years before the last menstrual period. Signs of perimenopause include:

*   More frequent periods at first
*   Occasional missed periods
*   Periods that are longer or shorter
*   Changes in the amount of menstrual flow

Eventually, periods become much less frequent until they stop completely.

**Physical Changes**

Along with changes in periods, physical changes occur in the reproductive tract. These include:

*   Vaginal walls becoming thinner, dryer, less elastic, and possibly irritated
*   Increased risk for vaginal yeast infections
*   External genital tissue decreasing and thinning, and becoming irritated

Other common changes include:

*   Menopause symptoms such as hot flashes, moodiness, headaches, and trouble sleeping
*   Problems with short-term memory
*   Decrease in breast tissue
*   Lower sex drive (libido) and sexual response
*   Increased risk for bone loss (osteoporosis)
*   Urinary system changes, such as frequency and urgency of urination and increased risk for urinary tract infection
*   Loss of tone in the pubic muscles, resulting in the vagina, uterus, or urinary bladder falling out of position (prolapse)

**Managing Changes**

Hormone therapy with estrogen or progesterone may help menopause symptoms such as hot flashes or vaginal dryness and pain with intercourse. Most women who have a uterus will require progesterone as well as estrogen. Women without a uterus may take estrogen only. Hormone therapy has risks, so it is not for every woman. Discuss the risks and benefits of hormone therapy with your provider.

To help manage problems such as painful sexual intercourse, use a lubricant during sexual intercourse. Vaginal moisturizers are available without a prescription. These can help with vaginal and vulvar discomfort due to the drying and thinning of tissues. Applying topical estrogen inside the vagina may help thicken the vaginal tissues and increase moisture and sensitivity. Your provider can tell you if any of these measures is right for you.

Getting regular exercise, eating healthy foods, and staying involved in activities with friends and loved ones can help the aging process go more smoothly.

**Other Aging Changes**

Other aging changes to expect include:

*   Hormone production
*   Organs, tissues, and cells
*   Breasts
*   Kidneys

---

**Aging Changes in the Female Reproductive System**

\n\nAs women age, their reproductive systems undergo significant changes. One of the most notable effects of aging is the decline in estrogen levels, which can lead to a range of symptoms and health issues.

**Estrogen Deficiency**

Estrogen deficiency is a common consequence of menopause, but it can also occur in younger women due to various medical conditions or treatments such as chemotherapy or surgery. The effects of estrogen deficiency can be far-reaching, impacting not only reproductive health but also overall well-being.

**Effects of Hormone Therapy**

Hormone therapy has been widely used to alleviate symptoms associated with menopause and estrogen deficiency. However, the effectiveness and safety of hormone therapy are still debated among medical professionals. Some studies suggest that hormone therapy may provide relief from hot flashes, night sweats, and vaginal dryness, while others raise concerns about increased risks of breast cancer, blood clots, and stroke.

**Other Treatment Options**

In addition to hormone therapy, other treatment options are available for women experiencing symptoms related to estrogen deficiency. These may include:

*   *Vaginal estrogen creams or tablets*: To alleviate vaginal dryness and discomfort during sex
*   *Systemic estrogen therapy*: For women who cannot use vaginal estrogen due to certain medical conditions or preferences
*   *Non-hormonal medications*: Such as antidepressants, anticonvulsants, or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) to manage hot flashes and other symptoms

**References**

For further reading on this topic, consider the following references:

*   Lobo RA. Menopause and care of the mature woman: endocrinology, consequences of estrogen deficiency, effects of hormone therapy, and other treatment options. In: Gershenson DM, Lentz GM, Valea FA, Lobo RA, eds. Comprehensive Gynecology. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2022:chap 14.
*   Santoro N, Neal-Perry G. Menopause. In: Goldman L, Schafer AI, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 26th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 227.
*   van den Beld AW, Lamberts SWJ. Endocrinology and aging. In: Melmed S, Auchus RJ, Goldfine AB, Koenig RJ, Rosen CJ, eds. Williams Textbook of Endocrinology. 14th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 28.
*   White BA, Harrison JR, Mehlmann LM. Life cycle of the male and female reproductive systems. In: White BA, Harrison JR, Mehlmann LM, eds. Endocrine and Reproductive Physiology. 5th ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2019:chap 8.

**Review Date**

This article was last reviewed on November 10, 2022, by John D. Jacobson, MD, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Loma Linda University School of Medicine, Loma Linda, CA. Also reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

title: Aging changes in the heart and blood vessels: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes in the Heart and Blood Vessels**

Some changes in the heart and blood vessels normally occur with age. However, many other changes that are common with aging are due to or worsened by modifiable factors. If not treated, these can lead to heart disease.

**Background**

The heart has two sides. The right side pumps blood to the lungs to receive oxygen and get rid of carbon dioxide. The left side pumps oxygen-rich blood to the body.

Blood flows out of the heart, first through the aorta, and then through arteries, which branch out and get smaller and smaller as they go into the tissues. In the tissues, they become tiny capillaries.

Capillaries are where the blood gives up (releases) oxygen and nutrients to the tissues, and receives carbon dioxide and wastes back from the tissues. Then, the vessels begin to collect together into larger and larger veins, which return blood to the heart.

**Aging Changes**

* **Heart:**
	+ The natural pacemaker system that controls the heartbeat may develop fibrous tissue and fat deposits.
	+ The sinoatrial or SA node loses some of its cells, resulting in a slightly slower heart rate.
	+ A slight increase in the size of the heart, especially the left ventricle occurs in some people.
	+ The heart wall thickens, so the amount of blood that the chamber can hold may actually decrease despite the increased overall heart size.
	+ Heart changes often cause the electrocardiogram (ECG) of a normal, healthy older person to be slightly different than the ECG of a healthy younger adult.
	+ Abnormal rhythms (arrhythmias), such as atrial fibrillation, are more common in older people.
	+ Deposits of the "aging pigment," lipofuscin occur in the heart muscle cells.
	+ The valves inside the heart, which control the direction of blood flow, thicken and become stiffer.
* **Blood Vessels:**
	+ Receptors called baroreceptors monitor the blood pressure and make changes to help maintain a fairly constant blood pressure when a person changes positions or is doing other activities. The baroreceptors become less sensitive with aging.
	+ This may explain why many older people have orthostatic hypotension, a condition in which the blood pressure falls when a person goes from lying or sitting to standing.
	+ The capillary walls thicken slightly, causing a slightly slower rate of exchange of nutrients and wastes.
	+ The main artery from the heart (aorta) becomes thicker, stiffer, and less flexible.
* **Blood:**
	+ Normal aging causes a reduction in total body water. As part of this, there is less fluid in the bloodstream, so blood volume decreases.
	+ The speed with which red blood cells are produced in response to stress or illness is reduced.
	+ Most of the white blood cells stay at the same levels, although certain white blood cells important to immunity (neutrophils) decrease in their number and ability to fight off bacteria.

**Effect of Changes**

Normally, the heart continues to pump enough blood to supply all parts of the body. However, an older heart may not be able to pump blood as well when you make it work harder.

Some of the things that make your heart work harder are:

Certain medicines
Emotional stress
Physical exertion
Illness
Infections
Injuries
Caffeine and other stimulants in the diet

**Common Problems**

Angina (chest pain caused by temporarily reduced blood flow to the heart muscle), shortness of breath with exertion, and heart attack can result from coronary artery disease.
Abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias) of various types can occur.
Anemia may occur, possibly related to malnutrition, chronic infections, blood loss from the gastrointestinal tract, or as a complication of other diseases or medicines.
Atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries) is very common. Fatty plaque deposits inside the blood vessels cause them to narrow and may totally block blood vessels.
Congestive heart failure is also very common in older people. In people older than 75, congestive heart failure occurs 10 times more often than in younger adults.
Coronary artery disease is fairly common. It is usually a result of atherosclerosis.
High blood pressure and orthostatic hypotension are more common with older age. Older people on blood pressure medicines need to work with their health care provider to find the best way to manage their high blood pressure. This is because too much medicine may cause low blood pressure and could lead to a fall.
Heart valve diseases are fairly common. Aortic stenosis, or narrowing of the aortic valve, is the most common valve disease in older adults.
Transient ischemic attacks (TIA) or strokes can occur if blood flow to the brain is disrupted.

**Prevention**

You can help your circulatory system (heart and blood vessels). Heart disease risk factors that you have some control over include high blood pressure, cholesterol levels, diabetes, obesity, and smoking.
Eat a heart-healthy diet with reduced amounts of saturated fat and cholesterol, and control your weight. Follow your provider's recommendations for treating high blood pressure, high cholesterol or diabetes. Reduce or stop smoking.
Men age 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked should be screened for aneurysms in their abdominal aorta usually with an ultrasound exam.

Get more exercise:

Exercise may help prevent obesity, and it helps people with diabetes control their blood sugar.
Exercise may help you maintain your abilities as much as possible, and it reduces stress.
Moderate exercise is one of the best things you can do to keep your heart, and the rest of your body, healthy. Consult with your provider before beginning a new exercise program. Exercise moderately and within your capabilities, but do it regularly.
People who exercise often have less body fat and smoke less than people who do not exercise. They also tend to have fewer blood pressure problems and less heart disease.

Have regular check-ups for your heart:

Have your blood pressure checked every year. If you have diabetes, heart disease, kidney problems, or certain other conditions, your blood pressure may need to be monitored more closely.
If your cholesterol level is normal, have it rechecked every 5 years. If you have diabetes, heart disease, kidney problems, or certain other conditions, your cholesterol may need to be monitored more closely.

---

**Aging Changes in the Heart and Blood Vessels**

Some changes in the heart and blood vessels normally occur with age. However, many other changes that are common with aging are due to or worsened by modifiable factors. If not treated, these can lead to heart disease.

**BACKGROUND**

The heart has two sides. The right side pumps blood to the lungs to receive oxygen and get rid of carbon dioxide. The left side pumps oxygen-rich blood to the body.

Blood flows out of the heart, first through the aorta, and then through arteries, which branch out and get smaller and smaller as they go into the tissues. In the tissues, they become tiny capillaries.

Capillaries are where the blood gives up (releases) oxygen and nutrients to the tissues, and receives carbon dioxide and wastes back from the tissues. Then, the vessels begin to collect together into larger and larger veins, which return blood to the heart.

**AGING CHANGES**

* **Heart:**
	+ The natural pacemaker system that controls the heartbeat may develop fibrous tissue and fat deposits.
	+ The sinoatrial or SA node loses some of its cells.
	+ A slight increase in the size of the heart, especially the left ventricle occurs in some people.
	+ The heart wall thickens, so the amount of blood that the chamber can hold may actually decrease despite the increased overall heart size.
	+ Heart changes often cause the electrocardiogram (ECG) of a normal, healthy older person to be slightly different than the ECG of a healthy younger adult.
	+ Abnormal rhythms (arrhythmias), such as atrial fibrillation, are more common in older people.
* **Blood vessels:**
	+ Receptors called baroreceptors monitor the blood pressure and make changes to help maintain a fairly constant blood pressure when a person changes positions or is doing other activities.
	+ The baroreceptors become less sensitive with aging.
	+ This may explain why many older people have orthostatic hypotension, a condition in which the blood pressure falls when a person goes from lying or sitting to standing.
	+ The capillary walls thicken slightly.
	+ The main artery from the heart (aorta) becomes thicker, stiffer, and less flexible.
* **Blood:**
	+ Normal aging causes a reduction in total body water.
	+ As part of this, there is less fluid in the bloodstream, so blood volume decreases.
	+ The speed with which red blood cells are produced in response to stress or illness is reduced.

**EFFECT OF CHANGES**

Normally, the heart continues to pump enough blood to supply all parts of the body. However, an older heart may not be able to pump blood as well when you make it work harder.

Some of the things that make your heart work harder are:

* Certain medicines
* Emotional stress
* Physical exertion
* Illness
* Infections
* Injuries
* Caffeine and other stimulants in the diet

**COMMON PROBLEMS**

Angina (chest pain caused by temporarily reduced blood flow to the heart muscle), shortness of breath with exertion, and heart attack can result from coronary artery disease.

Abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias) of various types can occur.

Anemia may occur, possibly related to malnutrition, chronic infections, blood loss from the gastrointestinal tract, or as a complication of other diseases or medicines.

Atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries) is very common. Fatty plaque deposits inside the blood vessels cause them to narrow and may totally block blood vessels.

Congestive heart failure is also very common in older people. In people older than 75, congestive heart failure occurs 10 times more often than in younger adults.

Coronary artery disease is fairly common. It is usually a result of atherosclerosis.

High blood pressure and orthostatic hypotension are more common with older age. Older people on blood pressure medicines need to work with their health care provider to find the best way to manage their high blood pressure. This is because too much medicine may cause low blood pressure and could lead to a fall.

Heart valve diseases are fairly common. Aortic stenosis, or narrowing of the aortic valve, is the most common valve disease in older adults.

Transient ischemic attacks (TIA) or strokes can occur if blood flow to the brain is disrupted.

Other problems with the heart and blood vessels include the following:

* Blood clots
* Deep vein thrombosis
* Thrombophlebitis
* Peripheral vascular disease, resulting in intermittent pain in the legs when walking (claudication)
* Varicose veins
* Aneurysms may develop in one of the major arteries from the heart or in the brain. Aneurysms are an abnormal widening or ballooning of a part of an artery due to weakness in the wall of the blood vessel. If an aneurysm bursts it may cause bleeding and death.

**PREVENTION**

You can help your circulatory system (heart and blood vessels). Heart disease risk factors that you have some control over include high blood pressure, cholesterol levels, diabetes, obesity, and smoking.

Eat a heart-healthy diet with reduced amounts of saturated fat and cholesterol, and control your weight. Follow your provider's recommendations for treating high blood pressure, high cholesterol or diabetes. Reduce or stop smoking.

Men age 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked should be screened for aneurysms in their abdominal aorta usually with an ultrasound exam.

Get more exercise:

---

**Aging Changes in the Heart and Blood Vessels**

As we age, our heart and blood vessels undergo natural changes that can affect our overall health. While some of these changes are inevitable, many others are due to or worsened by modifiable factors.

**The Heart**

*   The heart's natural pacemaker system may develop fibrous tissue and fat deposits.
*   The sinoatrial (SA) node loses some of its cells, leading to a slightly slower heart rate.
*   A slight increase in the size of the heart occurs, especially in the left ventricle.
*   The heart wall thickens, decreasing the amount of blood the chamber can hold despite increased overall heart size.
*   Heart changes often cause the electrocardiogram (ECG) of a normal, healthy older person to be slightly different than that of a healthy younger adult.

**Blood Vessels**

*   Receptors called baroreceptors become less sensitive with aging, leading to orthostatic hypotension and dizziness when changing positions.
*   The capillary walls thicken slightly, causing a slower rate of exchange of nutrients and wastes.
*   The main artery from the heart (aorta) becomes thicker, stiffer, and less flexible, making blood pressure higher and the heart work harder.

**Blood**

*   Normal aging causes a reduction in total body water, resulting in decreased blood volume.
*   The speed at which red blood cells are produced in response to stress or illness is reduced.
*   Certain white blood cells important for immunity (neutrophils) decrease in number and ability to fight off bacteria.

**Effect of Changes**

An older heart may not be able to pump blood as well when made to work harder. Factors that make the heart work harder include:

*   Certain medicines
*   Emotional stress
*   Physical exertion
*   Illness
*   Infections
*   Injuries
*   Caffeine and other stimulants in the diet

**Common Problems**

Some common problems resulting from aging changes in the heart and blood vessels include:

*   Angina (chest pain caused by temporarily reduced blood flow to the heart muscle)
*   Shortness of breath with exertion
*   Heart attack
*   Abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias)
*   Anemia
*   Atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries)
*   Congestive heart failure
*   Coronary artery disease
*   High blood pressure and orthostatic hypotension

By understanding these changes, we can take steps to prevent or manage age-related health issues.

---

**Aging Changes in the Heart and Blood Vessels**

As we age, our heart and blood vessels undergo significant changes that can increase our risk of cardiovascular disease. In this article, we will explore these changes and discuss ways to prevent or manage them.

**Common Problems with the Heart and Blood Vessels**

Some common problems with the heart and blood vessels include:

*   **Aortic stenosis**: a narrowing of the aortic valve that can lead to transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) or strokes if blood flow to the brain is disrupted.
*   **Blood clots**
*   **Deep vein thrombosis**
*   **Thrombophlebitis**
*   **Peripheral vascular disease**, which can cause intermittent pain in the legs when walking (claudication)
*   **Varicose veins**
*   **Aneurysms**: abnormal widenings or ballooning of a part of an artery due to weakness in the wall of the blood vessel. If an aneurysm bursts, it may cause bleeding and death.

**Prevention**

You can help your circulatory system (heart and blood vessels) by:

*   **Eating a heart-healthy diet**: reduce saturated fat and cholesterol intake
*   **Controlling your weight**: maintain a healthy weight to reduce the risk of obesity-related cardiovascular disease
*   **Following your provider's recommendations** for treating high blood pressure, high cholesterol, or diabetes
*   **Reducing or stopping smoking**: smoking is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease
*   **Exercising regularly**: moderate exercise can help prevent obesity and improve blood sugar control in people with diabetes

**Regular Check-ups**

Have your:

*   **Blood pressure checked every year**
*   **Cholesterol level rechecked every 5 years**, or more frequently if you have certain conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, or kidney problems.

By understanding these changes and taking steps to prevent or manage them, we can reduce our risk of cardiovascular disease and maintain a healthy circulatory system.

---

title: Aging changes in the kidneys and bladder: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes and Their Effects on the Kidneys and Bladder**

As you age, your kidneys and bladder change. This can affect their function.

**Changes in the Kidneys that Occur with Age:**

*   Amount of kidney tissue decreases and kidney function diminishes.
*   Number of filtering units (nephrons) decreases. Nephrons filter waste material from the blood.
*   Blood vessels supplying the kidneys can become hardened. This causes the kidneys to filter blood more slowly.

**Changes in the Bladder:**

*   The bladder wall changes. The elastic tissue becomes stiffer and the bladder becomes less stretchy. The bladder cannot hold as much urine as before.
*   The bladder muscles weaken.
*   The urethra can become partially or totally blocked. In women, this can be due to weakened muscles that cause the bladder or vagina to fall out of position (prolapse). In men, the urethra can become blocked by an enlarged prostate gland.

**Common Problems:**

Aging increases the risk of kidney and bladder problems such as:

*   Bladder control issues, such as leakage or urinary incontinence (not being able to hold your urine), or urinary retention (not being able to completely empty your bladder)
*   Bladder and other urinary tract infections (UTIs)
*   Chronic kidney disease

**When to Contact a Medical Professional:**

Contact your health care provider right away if you have any of the following:

*   Signs of a urinary tract infection, including fever or chills, burning when urinating, nausea and vomiting, extreme tiredness, or flank pain
*   Very dark urine or fresh blood in the urine
*   Trouble urinating
*   Urinating more often than usual (polyuria)
*   Sudden need to urinate (urinary urgency)

---

**Aging Changes in the Kidneys and Bladder**

As you grow older, your kidneys and bladder undergo significant changes that can affect their function. In this article, we will explore these changes and discuss how they impact kidney function and bladder control.

**Changes in the Kidneys**

With age, the kidneys undergo a range of changes that can impact their function. These changes include:

*   **Decline in kidney function**: In a healthy aging person, kidney function declines very slowly. However, illness, medicines, and other conditions can significantly degrade kidney function.
*   **Changes in kidney structure**: The kidneys themselves change with age, becoming less efficient at filtering waste and excess fluids from the blood.

**Changes in the Bladder**

The bladder also undergoes significant changes with age, including:

*   **Muscle changes**: Muscle changes and changes in the reproductive system can affect bladder control.
*   **Prostate gland enlargement**: In men, an enlarged prostate gland can block the flow of urine, leading to urinary retention.
*   **Prolapse**: In women, weakened muscles can cause the bladder or vagina to fall out of position, leading to prolapse.

**Common Problems**

Aging increases the risk of kidney and bladder problems such as:

*   **Bladder control issues**: Bladder control issues, such as leakage or urinary incontinence (not being able to hold your urine), or urinary retention (not being able to completely empty your bladder)
*   **Urinary tract infections**: Bladder and other urinary tract infections (UTIs)
*   **Chronic kidney disease**: Chronic kidney disease

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your health care provider right away if you have any of the following:

*   Signs of a urinary tract infection, including fever or chills, burning when urinating, nausea and vomiting, extreme tiredness, or flank pain
*   Very dark urine or fresh blood in the urine
*   Trouble urinating
*   Urinating more often than usual (polyuria)
*   Sudden need to urinate (urinary urgency)

title: Aging changes in the lungs: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes in Your Body and Their Effects on the Lungs**

As we age, our bodies undergo various changes that can affect our lungs. In this article, we'll explore these changes and how they impact our respiratory system.

**Changes to the Bones and Muscles of the Chest and Spine**

*   Bones become thinner and change shape, which can alter the shape of your ribcage.
*   The muscle that supports breathing, the diaphragm, becomes weakened.

These changes can lower oxygen levels in the body and reduce carbon dioxide removal, leading to symptoms like tiredness and shortness of breath.

**Changes to Lung Tissue**

*   Muscles and other tissues near airways lose their ability to keep them completely open.
*   Aging causes air sacs to lose shape and become baggy.

These changes can allow air to get trapped in the lungs, making it hard to breathe due to insufficient oxygen and carbon dioxide removal.

**Changes to the Nervous System**

*   The part of the brain controlling breathing may lose function, weakening automatic breathing functions.
*   Nerves that trigger coughing become less sensitive, making it harder to expel particles like smoke or germs.

These changes can lead to breathing difficulties due to inadequate oxygen intake and carbon dioxide removal.

**Changes to the Immune System**

*   The immune system weakens, making it harder for the body to fight lung infections and diseases.
*   Lungs are less able to recover from exposure to harmful particles like smoke.

As a result of these changes, older individuals are at increased risk for lung infections, shortness of breath, low oxygen levels, and abnormal breathing patterns that can lead to problems like sleep apnea.

---

**Aging Changes in the Lungs**

As we age, our lungs undergo significant changes that can affect their function and overall health. In this article, we'll explore these changes and discuss how to prevent or mitigate their effects.

**The Lungs' Main Functions**

Before diving into the specifics of aging changes, let's quickly review the lungs' two main functions:

*   Getting oxygen from the air into the body
*   Removing carbon dioxide from the body

Our bodies need oxygen to work properly, and carbon dioxide is a gas produced when we use oxygen.

**Aging Changes in the Lungs**

Now, let's discuss the changes that occur in our lungs as we age:

### **Changes to the Bones and Muscles of the Chest and Spine**

As we age, our bones become thinner and change shape. This can alter the shape of our ribcage, making it harder for our lungs to expand and contract during breathing. Additionally, the muscle that supports our breathing, the diaphragm, becomes weakened. This weakness may prevent us from breathing enough air in or out.

These changes in our bones and muscles may lower the oxygen level in our body. Also, less carbon dioxide may be removed from our body. Symptoms such as tiredness and shortness of breath can result.

### **Changes to Lung Tissue**

Muscles and other tissues near our airways may lose their ability to keep the airways completely open. This causes the airways to close easily. Aging also causes the air sacs to lose their shape and become baggy.

These changes in lung tissue can allow air to get trapped in our lungs. Too little oxygen may enter our blood vessels, and less carbon dioxide may be removed. This makes it hard to breathe.

### **Changes to the Nervous System**

The part of our brain that controls breathing may lose some of its function, weakening the automatic breathing functions. When this happens, our lungs are not able to get enough oxygen. Not enough carbon dioxide may leave the lungs. Breathing may get more difficult.

### **Changes to the Immune System**

Our immune system can get weaker as we age. This means our body is less able to fight lung infections and other diseases. Our lungs are also less able to recover after exposure to smoke or other harmful particles.

**Common Problems**

As a result of these changes, older people are at increased risk for:

*   Lung infections, such as pneumonia and bronchitis
*   Shortness of breath
*   Low oxygen level
*   Abnormal breathing patterns, resulting in problems such as sleep apnea (episodes of stopped breathing during sleep)

**Prevention**

To decrease the effects of aging on the lungs:

1.  **Do not smoke. Avoid exposure to cigarette smoke.** Smoking and smoke exposure harm the lungs and speeds up lung aging.
2.  **Do physical exercise to improve lung function.**
3.  **Get up and move.** Lying in bed or sitting for long periods allows mucus to collect in the lungs. This puts you at risk of lung infections. This is especially true right after surgery or when you are ill.

By following these tips, we can help mitigate the effects of aging on our lungs and maintain overall health and well-being.

---

**Aging Changes in the Lungs**

\n\n

**Age-Related Changes in Lung Tissue**

As we age, our lungs undergo significant changes that can impact our respiratory health. One of the key changes is the loss of elasticity in the lungs, making it harder to breathe and increasing the risk of lung diseases such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

\n\n

**Impact on Respiratory Function**

Aging also affects the respiratory system's ability to exchange gases. The diaphragm becomes less efficient, and the lungs become less compliant, leading to a decrease in vital capacity and forced expiratory volume.

\n\n

**Changes in Lung Tissue**

Studies have shown that lung tissue undergoes significant changes with age, including:

*   Loss of respiratory cilia
*   Decreased lung elasticity
*   Increased risk of lung diseases such as COPD

These changes can have a significant impact on our respiratory health and overall quality of life.

title: Aging changes in the male reproductive system: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes in the Male Reproductive System**

Unlike women, men do not experience a major, rapid change in fertility as they age (like menopause). Instead, changes occur gradually during a process that some people call andropause.

**Information**

Aging changes in the male reproductive system occur primarily in the testes. Testicular tissue mass decreases. The level of the male sex hormone, testosterone decreases gradually. There may be problems getting an erection. This is a general slowing, instead of a complete lack of function.

**Fertility**

The tubes that carry sperm may become less elastic (a process called sclerosis). The testes continue to produce sperm, but the rate of sperm cell production slows. The epididymis, seminal vesicles, and prostate gland lose some of their surface cells. But they continue to produce the fluid that helps carry sperm.

**Urinary Function**

The prostate gland enlarges with age as some of the prostate tissue is replaced with a scar like tissue. This condition, called benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), affects about 50% of men. BPH may cause problems with slowed urination and ejaculation.

In both men and women, reproductive system changes are closely related to changes in the urinary system.

**Effect of Changes**

Fertility varies from man to man. Age does not predict male fertility. Prostate function does not affect fertility. A man can father children, even if his prostate gland has been removed. Some fairly old men can (and do) father children.

The volume of fluid ejaculated usually remains the same, but there are fewer living sperm in the fluid.

Some men may have a lower sex drive (libido). Sexual responses may become slower and less intense. This may be related to a decreased testosterone level. It may also result from psychological or social changes due to aging (such as the lack of a willing partner), illness, long-term (chronic) conditions, or medicines.

Aging by itself does not prevent a man from being able to enjoy sexual relationships.

**Common Problems**

Erectile dysfunction (ED) may be a concern for aging men. It is normal for erections to occur less often than when a man was younger. Aging men are often less able to have repeated ejaculations.

**Prevention and Related Topics**

Many physical age-related changes, such as prostate enlargement or testicular atrophy, are not preventable. Getting treated for health disorders such as high blood pressure and diabetes may prevent problems with urinary and sexual function.

Changes in sexual response are most often related to factors other than simple aging. Older men are more likely to have good sex if they continue to be sexually active during middle age.

**References**

Brinton RD. Neuroendocrinology of aging. In: Fillit HM, Rockwood K, Young J, eds. Brocklehurst's Textbook of Geriatric Medicine and Gerontology. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:chap 13.

Standring S. Male reproductive system. In: Standring S, ed. Gray's Anatomy. 42nd ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier Limited; 2021:chap 74.

van den Beld AW, Lamberts SWJ. Endocrinology and aging. In: Melmed S, Auchus RJ, Goldfine AB, Koenig RJ, Rosen CJ, eds. Williams Textbook of Endocrinology. 14th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 28.

Walston JD. Common clinical sequelae of aging. In: Goldman L, Cooney KA, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 27th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 24.

---

**Aging Changes in the Male Reproductive System**

Unlike women, men do not experience a major, rapid (over several months) change in fertility as they age (like menopause). Instead, changes occur gradually during a process that some people call andropause.

**Information**

Aging changes in the male reproductive system occur primarily in the testes. Testicular tissue mass decreases. The level of the male sex hormone, testosterone decreases gradually. There may be problems getting an erection. This is a general slowing, instead of a complete lack of function.

**Fertility**

The tubes that carry sperm may become less elastic (a process called sclerosis). The testes continue to produce sperm, but the rate of sperm cell production slows. The epididymis, seminal vesicles, and prostate gland lose some of their surface cells. But they continue to produce the fluid that helps carry sperm.

**Urinary Function**

The prostate gland enlarges with age as some of the prostate tissue is replaced with a scar like tissue. This condition, called benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), affects about 50% of men. BPH may cause problems with slowed urination and ejaculation.

In both men and women, reproductive system changes are closely related to changes in the urinary system.

**Effect of Changes**

Fertility varies from man to man. Age does not predict male fertility. Prostate function does not affect fertility. A man can father children, even if his prostate gland has been removed. Some fairly old men can (and do) father children.

The volume of fluid ejaculated usually remains the same, but there are fewer living sperm in the fluid.

Some men may have a lower sex drive (libido). Sexual responses may become slower and less intense. This may be related to a decreased testosterone level. It may also result from psychological or social changes due to aging (such as the lack of a willing partner), illness, long-term (chronic) conditions, or medicines.

Aging by itself does not prevent a man from being able to enjoy sexual relationships.

**Common Problems**

Erectile dysfunction (ED) may be a concern for aging men. It is normal for erections to occur less often than when a man was younger. Aging men are often less able to have repeated ejaculations.

ED is most often the result of a medical problem, rather than simple aging. Ninety percent of ED is believed to be caused by a medical problem instead of a psychological problem.

Medicines (such as those used to treat hypertension and certain other conditions) can prevent a man from getting or keeping enough of an erection for intercourse. Disorders, such as diabetes, can also cause ED.

ED that is caused by medicines or illness is often successfully treated. Talk to your primary health care provider or a urologist if you are concerned about this condition.

BPH may eventually interfere with urination. The enlarged prostate partially blocks the tube that drains the bladder (urethra). Changes in the prostate gland make older men more likely to have urinary tract infections.

Urine may back up into the kidneys (vesicoureteral reflux) if the bladder is not fully drained. If this is not treated, it can eventually lead to kidney failure.

Prostate gland infections or inflammation (prostatitis) may also occur.

Prostate cancer becomes more likely as men age. It is one of the most common causes of cancer death in men. Bladder cancer also becomes more common with age. Testicular cancers are possible, but these occur more often in younger men.

**Prevention**

Many physical age-related changes, such as prostate enlargement or testicular atrophy, are not preventable. Getting treated for health disorders such as high blood pressure and diabetes may prevent problems with urinary and sexual function.

Changes in sexual response are most often related to factors other than simple aging. Older men are more likely to have good sex if they continue to be sexually active during middle age.

---

---

\n\n

**Response to aging factors**

Most responses to aging are related to factors other than simple aging. Older men are more likely to have good sex if they continue to be sexually active during middle age.

\n\n

**Related topics**

*   **Alternative Names**
    *   Andropause; Male reproductive changes
*   **Images**
    *   Young male reproductive system
    *   Aged male reproductive system

\n\n

**References**

*   Brinton RD. Neuroendocrinology of aging. In: Fillit HM, Rockwood K, Young J, eds. Brocklehurst's Textbook of Geriatric Medicine and Gerontology. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:chap 13.
*   Standring S. Male reproductive system. In: Standring S, ed. Gray's Anatomy. 42nd ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier Limited; 2021:chap 74.
*   van den Beld AW, Lamberts SWJ. Endocrinology and aging. In: Melmed S, Auchus RJ, Goldfine AB, Koenig RJ, Rosen CJ, eds. Williams Textbook of Endocrinology. 14th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 28.

title: Aging changes in the nervous system: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aging Changes in the Nervous System**

The brain and nervous system are your body's central control center. They control your body's:

* Movements
* Senses
* Thoughts and memories

They also help control the organs such as your heart and bowels.

Nerves are the pathways that carry signals to and from your brain and the rest of your body. The spinal cord is the bundle of nerves that runs from your brain down the center of your back. Nerves extend out from the spinal cord to every part of your body.

**Aging Changes and Their Effects on the Nervous System**

As you age, your brain and nervous system go through natural changes. Your brain and spinal cord lose nerve cells and weight (atrophy). Nerve cells may begin to pass messages more slowly than in the past. Waste products or other chemicals such as beta amyloid can collect in the brain tissue as nerve cells break down. This can cause abnormal changes in the brain called plaques and tangles to form. A fatty brown pigment (lipofuscin) can also build up in nerve tissue.

Breakdown of nerves can affect your senses. You might have reduced or lost reflexes or sensation. This leads to problems with movement and safety and makes it more likely to suffer falls.

Slowing of thought, memory, and thinking is a normal part of aging. These changes are not the same in everyone. Some people have many changes in their nerves and brain tissue. Others have few changes. These changes are not always related to the effects on your ability to think.

**Nervous System Problems in Older People**

Dementia and severe memory loss are not a normal part of aging. They can be caused by brain diseases such as Alzheimer disease, which doctors believe is associated with plaques and tangles forming in the brain.

Delirium is sudden confusion that leads to changes in thinking and behavior. It is often due to illnesses that are not related to the brain. Infection can cause an older person to become severely confused. Certain medicines can also cause or complicate this.

Thinking and behavior problems can also be caused by poorly controlled diabetes. Rising and falling blood sugar levels can interfere with thought.

Talk with your health care provider if you have any changes in:

* Memory
* Thought
* Ability to perform a task

Seek medical help right away if these symptoms occur suddenly or along with other symptoms. A change in thinking, memory, or behavior is important if it is different from your normal patterns or it affects your lifestyle.

**Prevention**

Mental and physical exercise can help your brain stay sharp. Mental exercises include:

* Reading
* Doing crossword puzzles
* Stimulating conversation

Physical exercise promotes blood flow to your brain. It also helps reduce loss of brain cells.

**Other Changes**

As you grow older, you will have other changes, including:

* In organs, tissues, and cells
* In the heart and blood vessels
* In the vital signs
* In the senses

---

As you age, your brain and nervous system go through natural changes. Your brain and spinal cord lose nerve cells and weight (atrophy). **Effects on the Nervous System**

Thinking and behavior problems can also be caused by poorly controlled diabetes. Rising and falling blood sugar levels can interfere with thought.

*   Doing crossword puzzles
*   Stimulating conversation

Physical exercise promotes blood flow to your brain. It also helps reduce loss of brain cells.

*   In the vital signs
